body: Which version of NUnit are you using and with what command line? We compile and on Linux with Mono, so we must be missing something. Can you provide more steps to reproduce?

Just updated everything to the last 3.0 RC; version of NUnit framework and console runner is 3.0.5790.16288, command line is just
`nunit3-console.exe --noc TestAssembly.dll`
Assembly compiled with MonoDevelop's xbuild engine version 12.0, with Mono Version 4.0.4.0 (from Xamarin's RPM repository, running on Fedora 21). All the assemblies in the solution target "Mono / .NET 4.5" (from Project Options).

Problem persists also with this last version; when starting the console runner, this is the output:
[console-runner-20151112.txt](https://github.com/nunit/nunit/files/33348/console-runner-20151112.txt)

If still cannot repro, will try to prepare a sample test case...

The error would have to be somewhat upstream. We'll have to figure out how the ClrVersion field of the RuntimeFramework object ends up with only two digits. Do you know what this version of mono puts into the assembly as the image runtime version?

Thank you for your fast responses; I checked the "image runtime version" using ILDASM on Windows, looking for "Metadata Version" as per http://blogs.msdn.com/b/suzcook/archive/2003/06/20/57191.aspx, however she says that the ImageRuntimeVersion of an Assembly may not be the actual required one.

ILDASM says the Metadata Version is 4.0.30319.

I also noticed that MonoDevelop did not update the DLL files (namely, nunit.framework.dll) in the output directory, so it kept an old version - 2.6.2 from net-40 directory. Once manually cleared the directory and rebuilt the solution, now the nunit.framework.dll version is in sync with the console runner, 3.0.5790, and is taken from the net-45 directory, and the problem disappears: the tests run correctly.

I don't think it is still a bug, when the assembly under test is linked to an old version (targeting a different framework, net-40) and the runner is new (and it crashes), so I think this issue can be closed - still, if you want to investigate on this problem, I'll try to help more.
Are you saying that your tests referenced the 3.0 nunit framework, but the 2.6.2 version of the framework was in the output directory?

Yes sir; due to a non-updated nunit.framework.dll in the output directory, the Assembly Under Test was actually loading the 2.6.2 (net-40) framework, while my console runner was version 3. My bad for not noticing this before.

rename.from: ArgumentException when targetRuntime.ClrVersion has only 2 fields
rename.to: ArgumentException when 2.x version of NUnit Framework is in the bin directory

body: Another thing I noticed: the same error occurs if the file name of the assembly under test does not exist. It may be related, i.e. some errors on the conflicting versions prevent an existing file from loading.

It's a pretty strange error. For one thing, if you have the 2.6.2 framework instead of the 3.0 framework, then your tests should fail to load with an error that indicates there is an assembly mismatch.

I wonder if this is one of those situations where an exception is thrown while trying to display the error message, thereby masking the original error?

That said, I think it's a low priority. When we create milestones for bug fixes we can consider this for promotion to 3.0.1, 3.0.2, etc.

I am having the same issue. Running
**mono NUnit.Console.3.0.1/tools/nunit3-console.exe myproject/nunit-lib.csproj --config=Debug**
results

> NUnit Console Runner 3.0.5813 
> Copyright (C) 2015 Charlie Poole
> 
> Runtime Environment
>    OS Version: Linux 4.1.10.17 
>   CLR Version: 4.6.57.0
> 
> Test Files
>     myproject/nunit-lib.csproj
> 
> System.ArgumentException: Argument must be between 0 and 2.
> Parameter name: fieldCount
>   at System.Version.ToString (Int32 fieldCount) <0x7fc3148c4650 + 0x00325> in <filename unknown>:0 
>   at NUnit.Engine.Services.TestAgency.LaunchAgentProcess (NUnit.Engine.TestPackage package) <0x4151dbb0 + 0x0068b> in <filename unknown>:0 
>   at NUnit.Engine.Services.TestAgency.CreateRemoteAgent (NUnit.Engine.TestPackage package, Int32 waitTime) <0x4151d980 + 0x00048> in <filename unknown>:0 
>   at NUnit.Engine.Services.TestAgency.GetAgent (NUnit.Engine.TestPackage package, Int32 waitTime) <0x4151d950 + 0x0001e> in <filename unknown>:0 
>   at (wrapper remoting-invoke-with-check) NUnit.Engine.Services.TestAgency:GetAgent (NUnit.Engine.TestPackage,int)
>   at NUnit.Engine.Runners.ProcessRunner.LoadPackage () <0x4151d2f0 + 0x00136> in <filename unknown>:0 

nunit-lib.csproj can be found from http://pastebin.com/gpHsSP9i and TestCases.cs from http://pastebin.com/i8rkuk6A

Does someone have any tip how to avoid this issue?

My best guess is that whatever you are using to compile is ignoring the 3.0.1 version of NUnit in your hint path and pulling the old version from the GAC.
- What distro of Linux?
- What version of Mono?
- Are you compiling command line or using MonoDevelop?
- How did you adding NUnit? It looks like  you are just browsing to it?

When I add a reference in Visual Studio, it adds the fully qualified nunit framework.

``` XML
    <Reference Include="nunit.framework, Version=3.0.5813.39031, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=2638cd05610744eb, processorArchitecture=MSIL">
      <HintPath>..\packages\NUnit.3.0.1\lib\net45\nunit.framework.dll</HintPath>
      <Private>True</Private>
    </Reference>
```

Whereas yours looks like this.

``` XML
    <Reference Include="nunit.framework">
      <HintPath>..\NUnit.3.0.1\lib\net45\nunit.framework.dll</HintPath>
    </Reference>
```

My guess is that because you haven't specified the version, it is ignoring the `HintPath` and using the version in the GAC.

Try the following,
- I am on a Windows machine, so cannot check this, but can you add something like `Use specific version` to the NUnit reference in MonoDevelop?
- If that doesn't work, edit your project file to be like mine, but with your hint path.

Does that fix it?
BTW, @mcraiha thanks for uploading your project file to pastebin. These things are much easier to diagnose when you can look at the code :+1:
